captions.text:
Time to debate Lincoln.
Oy.

You didn’t like Lincoln?
I liked it about as much as you can like a

2 and a half hour history lesson, sure.
(laughs)

You know those film strips they used to show
us back in high school? It was about as entertaining

as one of those.
That’s a huge overstatement, and you know

it.
Is it?

Yes it is.
Is this or is it not, at the end of the day,

a movie that’s about the passing of a piece
of legislation?

It is.
Might as well be an episode of The West Wing,

circa 1865, only with even less snappy banter.
That’s a good joke, but it’s not remotely

accurate, and you know it.
(THAT WAS EASY). Do you ever get tired of

losing to me in these debates?
I get tired of you scoring points without

actual debate, but I can do it too. Daniel
Day Lewis was awesome in this movie, and there

can be no argument. (THAT WAS EASY)
Liam Neeson would have been better.

What? What did you say?
Nothing. Alright, my turn. The speechifying.

The what?
The speechifying. You know how I knew Daniel

Day Lewis was going to win the Oscar for this
movie? Because every other scene in this movie

is a speech, soliloquy, or big storytelling
moment for Lincoln. The only scenes in the

movie that aren’t big Lincoln speeches are
the scenes where he’s walking from place

to place in between two big Lincoln speeches.
I think Lincoln himself was prone to giving

speeches and stories…
I don’t care if it’s all he ever did in

his old-timey life, it doesn’t make for
good cinema. They should have called it Best

Actor: The Movie. ( THAT WAS EASY)
Now, I’m gonna argue this with you becausetThe

speechifying was what made it good, you can’t
just go scoring points whenever you want to.

You know when I’m allowed to score points
for something like that? Now, now now! (THAT

WAS EASY)
You’re a dick.

Not as big a dick as Lincoln was to his son,
and that’s my next point. How can a movie

that celebrates a cold, distant, emotionally
abusive father like this as a hero be a good

movie? (THAT WAS EASY)
It worked for Star Wars.

Another problem… no suspense.
No suspense? You’ve gotta be kidding me.

There’s no suspense in this movie. From
the first few minutes I knew that they were

going to get the legislation passed.
That’s because it happened in real life!!

Exactly. Bad writing. Way too predictable.
Do you feel the same way about Apollo 13 then?

Well was Apollo 13 real?!
Yes. Yes.

I’m taking a point either way. (THAT WAS
EASY) And I’m also taking a point for the

ending, okay, where they cop out and show
his death.

You can’t do a Lincoln movie without showing
his death.

Then f*cking show it! Don’t flash forward,
allude to it, then flash back to another d*mn

speech. Alright? Have the balls to show it
if you’re gonna show it. But you just spent

the last two and a half hours telling me this
movie was about the legislation and not the

assassination, alright, so then have the balls
to end it without copping out and going to

the assassination.
I think maybe you--

(THAT WAS EASY) I’m also taking a point
because Lincoln’s dirty.

Lincoln is dirty?
He’s dirty man. He hires those lobbyists

to bribe, intimidate, coerce, and he basically
buys the vote. So this movie’s conclusion

is that dirty politics is okay, as long as
you’re right. And that doesn’t work because

every f*cking politician thinks they’re
right, and they can’t all be right. (THAT

WAS EASY)
If you think politicians are pure at all then

you probably think the Earth is flat.
Of course I do, don’t be an idiot.

The Earth is round, dumbass.
That’s what I said. Shut up. I know what
I said.

title: Conversations With Myself About Movies - Lincoln

comments.author: DrivenByDiamond

comments.text:
Thank you!  I don't agree with all of your points, but god, Lincoln was one 
of the dullest movies I've ever sat through.  I love history, it has been 
my favorite subject from the time I was ten-years-old.  I read history 
books for fun, and I found this movie to be boring.  I have no idea how 
anyone can call this movie good.  It wasn't entertaining and it was really 
only tangentially about Lincoln.  It was more about the legislation.  While 
the 13th amendment was one of the most important pieces of legislation this 
country has ever passed, it's pretty hard to establish an emotional 
connection with a law.  The movie should have been about people (maybe...I 
don't know, Lincoln?) instead it was about an ideology and it sucked 
because of it.﻿
comments.author: Mark Phillips

comments.author: Liam Welch

comments.text:
Maybe I'm just a history nerd, but I loved this movie for portraying in an 
accurate manner Lincoln's personal life and what kind of dirty work he had 
to do to get the Emancipation Proclamation passed. He questioned the powers 
that presidents were given, as the Constitution is vague on the matter.
This movie is an adaption of a historical time period mostly focused upon 
Lincoln's presidency leading up to his assassination. It was meant to be 
this way, therefore, since it does what it accomplished, it wins the prize 
of being a great movie in my book.﻿
comments.author: TulkasIV

comments.text: My apologies, sir. I bow before your superior common sense.
comments.author: TulkasIV

comments.text:
If you were such a huge history nerd you'd realize that the movie is about 
the 13th amendment to the Constitution, not the Emancipation Proclamation. 
 The Emancipation Proclamation didn't have to be passed because it was...a 
Presidential proclamation.
comments.author: Mark Phillips

comments.text:
I think the point of the movie was not "dirty politics are alright", I 
think it was saying that "it's not all sunshine and rainbows""You know, on 
one side it tells you that Lincoln was a person, and politician, not some 
golden-bearded angel, and on the other it also tries to make you appreciate 
the legislation more by showing the sort of opposition that it faced and 
the lows that had to be explored in order for it to pass. Well, that's my 
tuppence. I could be horribly inaccurate in my interpretation, I most 
likely am, but that's what I think.﻿

comments.text:
They didn't show his death to avoid giving John Wilkes Booth any spotlight. 
One can argue this was done to not give those ever-so-present, stubborn, 
ignorant Confederates (that just refuse to accept facts) the satisfaction 
of seeing the death of President Lincoln.
comments.author: Dannymartialarts

comments.text:
Important Confederate leaders said it was about freaking slavery! If anyone 
had an incentive to say otherwise, it was them! The issue of slavery being 
the primary cause of the civil war is one of the most easily verified 
historical facts in existence. Of course state's rights, as well as the 
right to secede, were important issues, and it's unfortunate how some of 
them were tied to the cause promoting slavery, but to suggest that slavery 
as an issue was invented in 1862 is absolutely ludicrous.
comments.author: SV67943

comments.text: How. Dare. You.

comments.text:
Well I was going to counter argue. But I see the bile you put forth towards 
other posters for stating to you pure facts. This sort of behavior makes me 
not want to engage you further. Good day to you.
comments.author: MrThundaro

comments.text:
I'm inclined to agree with you, however many don't, and they are no less 
moral for it. Do you see what I mean? If you agree that the morality of 
abolishing slavery outweighs the immorality of dirty politics, Which is the 
moral path: to keep the institution of slavery or to engage in corruption?
comments.author: jimjam485

comments.text:
The problem is EVERYONE thinks that their goal justifies their means. This 
is basically never the case. Unless it is an immediate life or death 
situation. It never does.
comments.author: MrThundaro

comments.text:
That's a fair point, however I believe it's a matter of whether or not one 
believes the ends justify the means.
comments.author: jimjam485

comments.text:
The South fired the first shot, not the Union. You do realize that it's 
Congress that imposes tariffs, right? and that Southern politicians chose 
to not be represented? You say slavery was never an issue. Tell me this, 
why did the states secede? Living in the South, I hate people like you that 
claim things like the Civil War was fought over state's rights. It makes us 
look like we're still backwards.
comments.author: jimjam485

comments.text:
That's poor history. To imply keeping the union in tact and the 
emancipation of the slaves are simply instant gratifications is the thing 
that is ignorant. Also, that type of corruption did not stem from Lincoln. 
suspending habeus corpus, goes to Adams. Giving those who vote your way 
jobs and intimidating those who plan not to are as old as the republic, and 
was present in our mother country's parliament. I say Grant and Hayes 
embody scandals and corruption much more than Lincoln before them.
comments.author: jimjam485

comments.text: I love that you know what West Wing was, even if you're making fun of it.

comments.text:

movie that is supposed to have a moral "footing".

comments.text:
of 75,000 volunteers to invade and force the south into the union. Slavery 
was never an issue in the civil war and it only arose in September, 1862 
after the battle of Sharpsburg (Antietam).
comments.author: Spent Lizard

comments.text:
I liked this movie because it showed some truths about Lincoln. He did 
bribe and coerce others to pass the 13th amendment and he suspended Habeas 
Corpus (or jailed people without trials) and arrested 40,000 people. He 
also imposed the Morel Tariff on Southerners (without their representation) 
on their cotton exports which went up to 50% (the south generated 75% of 
the country's income). So, the southern states seceded (which they had 
every right to do so) and Lincoln decided to raise an army
comments.author: Spent Lizard
